2.07.text:
MALE SPEAKER: OK, I
think we're ready to go,

5.87.text:
It's another exciting
talk at Google.

8.56.text: We're glad you could join us.

10.12.text: Today we are hosting Bill Ury.

12.47.text:
He is the author of many
of the definitive works

15.52.text:
in the field of negotiation, the
co-author of "Getting to Yes,

20.51.text:
The current book is "Getting
to Yes With Yourself."

23.35.text:
And the idea behind
it is to take

25.64.text:
the sort of personal
and introspective look

28.24.text:
as a means towards approaching
the negotiation table.

31.89.text:
So in many ways, this is
the prequel, the prelude,

34.89.text:
to his other works,
and it could even

37.02.text:
help foster the conditions
for world peace.

40.52.text:
Bill is also the co-founder
of the Program on Negotiation

46.46.text:
at Harvard University and
has a very distinguished

49.10.text:
international career on the
negotiation circuit as well.

52.83.text:
So without further
ado, please join me

59.47.text:
WILLIAM URY: Well,
it's a great pleasure

61.14.text: to be here speaking a Google.

63.16.text:
I have a great debt
to Google because I

67.08.text:
And it makes my life a lot
easier, and some of my projects

71.82.text:
actually also benefit from
Google in the form of AdWords.

75.10.text:
So it's just a huge
pleasure to be here,

77.02.text:
and I really have
enjoyed the campus.

79.72.text:
What I want to talk
to you about is

82.40.text:
what I regard as perhaps the
most important competence

87.79.text:
that we need in today's
times, and that's

89.70.text:
the competence of
getting to yes.

91.88.text:
Aside from coding,
perhaps, getting to yes

94.95.text:
is a really important skill
for reaching agreements,

103.51.text: And it is not always easy.

105.60.text:
I've had the privilege of
having a kind of a front seat

109.11.text:
for the last 30 or 35
years on a revolution

113.15.text:
that's taking place around
the world that accompanies

115.57.text:
the knowledge revolution,
accompanies the information

120.53.text:
And that's a revolution in
the way in which individuals

123.80.text:
such as ourselves, organizations
such as yours, and societies

130.19.text:
Because traditionally, a
generation or more ago,

133.40.text:
maybe, the preeminent
process for making decisions

135.76.text:
was the people on the top
of the pyramids of power,

139.50.text:
And the people on the
bottom follow the orders.

141.99.text:
But nowadays, thanks to
the knowledge revolution,

145.13.text:
those pyramids of
power are increasingly

151.86.text:
that resemble networks,
like Google, where

155.00.text:
the form of decision
making shifts from vertical

158.57.text:
And another name for horizontal
decision making is negotiation.

163.21.text:
And what I've also
seen is that when

165.07.text:
I started in this
area of negotiation,

167.58.text:
most people had a
notion of negotiation

169.37.text:
as being kind of who's
going to win this.

172.82.text:
And that's shifted over time,
as the logic has shifted

176.08.text:
to one into which can we
both satisfy our basic needs.

181.75.text: Can we both win, as it were?

183.56.text:
Can we achieve, you know, a
classic, win-win solution.

188.45.text:
Today, these days, conflict
is a growth industry.

191.74.text:
And if you look
around at the news,

193.66.text:
it seems like people
or just as often

196.02.text:
getting to no as they
are getting to yes.

198.88.text:
And so my question is, what
stops us from getting to yes?

203.03.text:
So what I'd like to
do if I may just begin

205.09.text:
is just to kind of draw
you out a little bit

206.92.text:
about your own experiences
as negotiators.

209.91.text:
Because like it or not,
we are all negotiators.

213.18.text:
If I were to define negotiation
very simply and very broadly

219.85.text:
trying to reach some
kind of agreement.

222.03.text:
And you may have some interests
that you hold in common,

224.36.text:
like an ongoing relationship,
and you have other interests

226.97.text:
which are in tension,
like you would

229.53.text:
like to get more money for
your products and services.

231.82.text:
They would like
to give you less.

233.19.text:
Or, you know, you've
got the budget.

235.25.text:
You'd like a larger
slice of that budget.

238.23.text:
In that broad sense
of the term, who

240.13.text:
do you find yourself negotiating
with in the course of your day,

243.28.text:
would you say,
just to kind of see

244.74.text:
what the variety of
your situations are?

253.38.text:
That's not always so
easy to negotiate.

256.82.text:
So who else do you
negotiate besides your kids?

260.57.text:
Significant others, OK, so
some of the tough negotiations

265.76.text: Who else do you negotiate with?

274.90.text:
Yourself-- on the one hand,
you want to push yourself.

279.14.text:
On the other side,
there's a part of you

282.22.text:
OK, so there's this negotiation
inside of ourselves.

286.05.text:
So if you were to
just make a ballpark

289.48.text:
estimate of how
much of your time

295.28.text:
in the act of back-and-forth
communication,

297.27.text:
trying to reach
agreement with your kids,

299.71.text:
your significant other, your
colleagues, your coworkers,

309.27.text:
what percentage of
your time do you

310.73.text:
think you spend engaged
in this process.

312.73.text:
If you had to take a
guess, what would you say?

319.34.text:
OK, how many would
agree with that?

322.37.text:
OK, how many would say
it's even more than half?

325.24.text:
OK, so whatever it is, that's
a huge chunk of our time.

332.23.text:
And we may not
always think of it

334.04.text:
in the formal sense
as negotiation,

336.00.text:
but in the broad
sense of the term,

338.16.text:
this is a process we're engaged
in from the moment we get up

341.35.text:
in the morning to the moment
we got to bed at night.

344.32.text:
So let me ask you a couple
other questions here.

349.14.text:
If you were to think
back over the last 10

354.03.text:
years of your careers--
you've kind of risen up

358.48.text:
and you have more
authority and so

360.19.text:
on-- would you say
the amount of time

362.11.text:
that you spend negotiating has
stayed pretty much the same?

365.35.text: Has it gone down over time?

369.34.text:
Up, how many would
say it's gone up?

373.70.text:
So that's what I call this
negotiation revolution.

378.83.text:
There's a kind of a
negotiation revolution.

380.65.text:
I see it in every
country I visit.

382.76.text:
As the form of
decision making shifts,

388.25.text:
for making decisions, not
just at work, but at home,

392.82.text:
in our communities, in politics,
in the world-- and the question

397.77.text:
is, how do we learn
to do it better?

399.38.text:
And my question is what
stops us from getting to yes?

406.31.text:
Let me ask you,
just for a moment,

408.02.text:
just to take one any situation
you'd like just to have in mind

411.92.text:
as we talk about this
subject of getting

414.98.text: to yes for the next hour.

417.15.text:
Take any situation that
you'd like to focus on,

419.63.text:
some negotiation you're involved
in, could be with your child,

424.04.text:
it could be with your
significant other,

425.71.text: it could be with a coworker.

430.88.text:
that's been maybe a little
problematic for you,

438.24.text:
So then let me ask you if there
are two kinds of negotiations.

443.35.text:
There are the external
negotiations that are outside,

447.28.text:
let's say, with customers,
with suppliers, you know,

449.89.text:
standardly what we talk
about as negotiation.

452.66.text:
And then there are the
negotiations inside,

454.78.text:
like inside the family
or inside your work unit.

458.88.text:
How many of you, just
out of curiosity,

460.75.text:
have just selected an
external negotiation?

463.77.text:
That was what came
to mind when you

465.23.text:
were thinking about
a problematic one.

469.35.text:
OK, a lot of
internal-- and so if I

472.62.text:
ask you this question
of if you were

475.30.text:
to make a broad
generalization, just

477.19.text:
from your own experience, which
is more problematic for you--

481.52.text:
the external negotiations
or the internal ones?

485.17.text:
Which ones tend to
give you more trouble?

487.09.text:
How many would say it's
external gives me more trouble?

490.20.text:
OK, how many would say it's
internal gives me more trouble?

494.60.text:
If you look around the
room, it's like 90%.

498.03.text:
Now obviously both
can be problematic.

500.25.text:
And in fact, a lot of
external negotiations

504.50.text: But so my question is this.

508.46.text:
Because basically my passion
for the last 35 years

514.71.text:
societies get to yes, from
family feuds to boardroom

518.07.text:
battles, from labor
strikes to civil wars

520.83.text: in different parts of the world.

523.18.text:
And the thing that's
kind of struck

524.64.text:
me is that, actually, when
I think about what makes

529.78.text:
negotiations very difficult,
what I've gradually come

531.99.text:
to realize is that the
negotiation with ourselves--

537.64.text:
you know, what could be more
internal than the negotiation

540.85.text:
Because it seems
like we experience

546.53.text:
but perhaps the most problematic
is the one with ourselves.

549.67.text:
And this is what I've found
is that perhaps our biggest

553.80.text:
opponent, the biggest obstacle
to us getting what we want

561.22.text:
in life and in our
negotiations, is not

564.17.text: what we often think it is.

565.83.text:
It's not just the other person
across on the other side

571.08.text:
That person can
be very difficult.

572.50.text:
Those people can
be very difficult.

574.15.text:
And I've specialized in
dealing with difficult people

578.43.text:
But I find that however
difficult that person

580.36.text:
is, the most difficult
person we have to deal with

583.13.text:
is-- I have to deal with,
at least-- is right here.

587.63.text:
We are, in some ways,
our own biggest opponent.

591.71.text:
That's the person we look at
in the mirror every morning.

594.08.text:
That's the person who's going
to give us the most trouble.

596.94.text:
I think it was President
Teddy Roosevelt who once said,

602.96.text:
if you could give
a kick in the pants

605.94.text:
to the person who will give
you the most trouble in life,

610.19.text: you would not sit for a month.

613.43.text:
We are often our
own worst enemies

615.99.text:
because we human beings, for one
thing, we're reaction machines.

622.11.text:
We tend to react
in ways to do not

628.53.text:
And so my question is, how
do we turn that biggest

639.90.text:
opponent of ours into
our biggest ally?

644.90.text:
That's what I think
of as the process

647.26.text: of getting to yes with yourself.

648.95.text:
How do you turn your own
opponent, yourself as opponent,

654.97.text:
And what I've found is
that what we tend to do

657.64.text:
is it's almost as if
we get in our own way.

661.65.text:
And it's almost as if
we've been negotiating.

665.67.text:
And the way I've tended to
focus on negotiation, always

668.63.text: on the other side of the table.

669.92.text:
And I realize that
part the problem

671.45.text: is on this side of the table.

673.67.text:
And it's almost as if we've been
negotiating with one arm tied

676.25.text:
behind our back because
we're negotiating just

680.82.text:
focused on the external,
influencing the other person,

683.37.text:
when in fact our
biggest opportunity

685.36.text:
is to start off by influencing
this person right here.

689.00.text:
And so what I'd like to do
with you for a moment is just--

694.54.text:
from that realization,
I've kind of

696.31.text:
come to realize that getting
to yes is an inside job.

700.24.text:
And so what I'd like to do is
talk about how do we do that.

704.94.text:
How do we handle that first
and perhaps most important

708.01.text:
negotiation that
we ever engage in,

710.01.text: the one that starts from within?

711.69.text:
What are some principles of how
do you get to yes with yourself

716.92.text:
as the first step towards
getting to yes with others?

721.14.text:
How do we do that
in our homework?

722.56.text:
And I know here-- I
just had the pleasure

725.30.text:
of spending several
hours with Meng,

727.00.text:
and I know you
have these courses

729.81.text:
about searching Inside yourself
and doing that work of self

733.54.text:
awareness and of attention
training and so on.

736.46.text:
So this will be very congruent
with that kind of work.

742.24.text:
What I'd like to do is
just review with you

745.23.text:
And then I'd like to leave
time for some questions,

747.35.text:
so we can go into any
of your situations

749.25.text:
or any questions you might
have about negotiation.

751.85.text:
But I'm going to go over
some principles that

755.77.text:
are the very same principles
we might apply outwards,

759.44.text: but to apply them inwards first.

762.00.text:
I think of them as the
psychological antecedents

765.25.text:
to the process of
getting to yes.

769.07.text:
So the first, and
maybe the foundation,

773.41.text:
that I've been teaching for
many years around negotiation

776.91.text:
is the ability
to-- I like to use

779.50.text:
the metaphor of
going to the balcony.

785.21.text:
like you're negotiating
up here on a stage.

787.93.text:
Part of your mind goes to a
mental or emotional balcony

792.14.text:
overlooking that stage, which
is a place of perspective.

798.86.text: It's a place of self control.

801.08.text:
It's a place where you can
keep your eyes on the prize,

807.55.text:
We're often reacting
out of fear.

811.15.text:
And as the old saying
goes, when angry,

814.61.text:
you will make the best
speech you will ever regret.

818.64.text:
And we sometimes get brought
into a process of either

823.69.text:
attacking the other side
sometimes out of anger,

827.10.text:
or accommodating, giving in,
to the other side out of fear,

834.33.text:
How many of you, just out of
curiosity, if I ever ask you--

838.64.text:
I sometimes think of this as the
three A's-- you know, attack,

843.84.text:
If you said, I have a
tendency to accommodate,

847.98.text:
how many would say that you
have a tendency to accommodate?

851.66.text:
I would say you have a
tendency to attack more

856.08.text:
How many would say you
have a tendency to avoid?

858.87.text:
OK, and sometimes we use a
combination of all of them.

864.12.text:
We may accommodate for a
long time with our child,

867.45.text: and then we suddenly lose it.

869.98.text:
You've been to that
movie, you know?

871.48.text:
And then we attack, and
then we go back to avoiding.

876.52.text:
The question is, is
there a better way?

878.17.text:
And I think there
is a better way

879.55.text:
of getting to yes, which
is actually engaging

881.45.text:
the differences in
a constructive way.

883.40.text:
But in order to do
that, it requires

885.20.text: us to go to the balcony.

886.37.text:
And it's hard to go to
the balcony these days.

892.22.text:
all our technology and cell
phones and texts and tweets

896.02.text:
and everything that's going on,
it's so easy to get reactive.

900.77.text:
I mean, for example, you're
sitting there at your computer

904.39.text:
and you get an email that you
suddenly felt, wait a minute.

908.63.text:
They didn't consult
me on that decision.

910.30.text:
And you kind of feel
ticked off and irritated.

912.22.text:
So it's just very natural
to compose a reply.

919.90.text:
But you don't just
hit the Reply button,

921.66.text: you hit the Reply All button.

923.73.text:
And then it goes out to
the entire organization

926.46.text:
and you start to see
conflicts start to escalate.

929.09.text:
There is a button on that
screen that is often rarely used

932.63.text:
that I think of as
the balcony button,

934.27.text: and it says, Save as Draft.

937.34.text:
That's the one where you
get it out of your system.

939.55.text: You save it as a draft.

941.23.text:
Then everyone has their
favorite techniques

944.74.text:
Some people might, you
know, breathe or meditate.

947.66.text:
Some people might go for a walk
in these lovely surroundings

951.03.text:
here or go have a cup of coffee
with a friend or sleep on it.

954.84.text:
But you're going to come
back after a few minutes

957.56.text:
You're going to
look at that email

958.98.text:
and you're going to ask
yourself the important question.

961.31.text:
Is this going to
advance my interests?

964.47.text:
Is this really going to serve
the needs of the situation?

967.73.text:
And most likely you're going
to hit the Delete button,

971.39.text:
and then you're going to pick up
the phone and call the person,

974.08.text:
get together with
them or however

975.84.text: to try to resolve the situation.

977.26.text:
Because email as it turns
out, while it's a great way

980.47.text:
to convey information,
is not such a great way

984.07.text:
to deal with anything
that's emotionally delicate.

987.16.text:
So those are all ways
of going to the balcony.

992.25.text:
But the question
is, a lot of people

993.83.text:
find that they fall
off the balcony.

998.63.text:
And so the question is how
can we say on the balcony?

1000.84.text:
And so this brings me
to the next principle,

1004.94.text:
which is one of the key
principles of negotiation.

1007.02.text:
I mean, if people ask me,
what's the most important skill

1010.72.text:
that a negotiator
needs to have-- there

1012.34.text:
are a lot of skills
that we need to have,

1014.05.text:
but if I had to pick one--
usually I pick this one.

1016.63.text:
It's the ability to put yourself
in the other side's shoes,

1020.53.text:
in other words, the ability
to try and understand

1023.96.text:
what your coworker really
wants or what your child wants

1027.41.text:
or what your
significant other wants.

1030.61.text:
Because after all, negotiation
is an exercise in influence.

1034.08.text:
You're trying to
change someone's mind.

1036.20.text:
How can we possibly
change their mind

1039.17.text:
if we don't know
where their mind is?

1041.84.text:
So putting yourself
in their shoes is key.

1043.99.text:
But what I've discovered
in teaching this over many,

1046.94.text:
many years is that it's
not easy for people

1049.65.text:
to put themselves in
the other side's shoes.

1052.35.text:
It's not easy for us to listen
to others because there's

1054.91.text:
so much going on for
us in our own minds

1057.93.text:
already that there's no mental
or emotional space for us

1062.27.text:
to be able to invite in the
other person's concerns.

1066.45.text:
And so the biggest block to
us being able to put ourselves

1069.56.text:
in the other side's
shoes-- which is key

1071.38.text:
if you're dealing with
customers or clients or anything

1073.67.text:
like that, it's absolutely key--
but the biggest block is us.

1077.02.text:
And so what I
found paradoxically

1078.77.text:
is that there is a psychological
antecedent to putting ourselves

1083.29.text:
in the other person's
shoes, and that's

1085.44.text:
to put ourselves in
our own shoes first.

1089.59.text:
In other words, not
just to listen to them,

1092.72.text:
but before we can
listen to them properly,

1094.47.text: we need to listen to ourselves.

1097.16.text:
We need to be able to see
ourselves from the balcony.

1099.84.text:
We need to be able to practice
the skills of self observation

1106.79.text:
I think it was Benjamin
Franklin who centuries ago said,

1110.54.text:
observe all people,
yourself most of all.

1115.07.text:
So what I'd like to do is
tell you a little story,

1119.41.text:
just if I may, from
my own experience

1121.68.text:
of when I began to really focus
on this whole issue of how

1128.24.text:
I was involved some
years ago as a mediator

1139.36.text:
I had been asked
by President Carter

1142.12.text:
to be a third party in between
the government of Venezuela,

1147.86.text:
the president whose name was
Hugo Chavez-- some of you

1150.57.text:
may remember him-- and
the political opposition.

1154.37.text:
And it was a time when there
were about a million people

1157.36.text:
on the streets of
Caracas, the capital city,

1160.27.text:
demanding the resignation of the
president and a million people

1165.08.text:
And there was some
violence, and people

1166.70.text:
were genuinely afraid it
might lead to a civil war.

1169.88.text:
Anyway, at one point-- I
had a number of meetings

1172.02.text:
with President Chavez--
but one of them--

1175.03.text:
he was a kind of complex and
somewhat volatile individual--

1179.82.text:
but at one of them, we had
a meeting with my friend

1183.08.text:
Francisco, colleague
Francisco, set at 9 o'clock.

1185.42.text:
He liked to meet at night
in the presidential palace.

1190.14.text:
And finally midnight came
and we were ushered in

1194.18.text:
Instead of finding
him alone at midnight,

1195.89.text:
we found his entire
cabinet arrayed behind him.

1199.57.text: He said, have a seat here.

1201.43.text:
Now tell me what do you
think of the situation here?

1207.66.text:
And I said, well, you
know, Mr. President, I've

1209.62.text:
been talking to some of your
government ministers here

1211.88.text:
and some of the opposition
and it seems to me

1217.07.text:
As soon as he heard the word
progress, he got triggered.

1219.40.text:
He said, what do
you mean progress?

1221.86.text:
You're not seeing
the dirty tricks

1223.65.text:
those traitors in the
opposition are up to.

1227.11.text:
And he proceeded to get furious,
leaned in very close to my face

1231.07.text:
and started to yell for
approximately 30 minutes,

1237.36.text: in front of his entire cabinet.

1238.71.text:
Now if you put yourself in my
shoes, I was kind of going,

1243.39.text:
You're trying to defend yourself
and thinking about that.

1246.78.text:
But then, thankfully,
I was able to go

1249.23.text:
to the balcony for a
moment and ask myself

1253.19.text:
Is it really going to advance

1256.22.text:
for me to get into an

1259.73.text: So I thought the better of it.

1263.42.text:
And sure enough,

1265.80.text:
could go on for eight hours,

If I had interrupted him

1271.75.text:
I'm sure it could have

And I was thinking in

1278.26.text:
here in Venezuela

You get reactive in

1282.15.text:
when someone is shouting

But somehow I was able

1290.41.text:
And I saw after 30 minutes,

1295.92.text:
I saw his shoulders kind

1298.49.text:
And in a weary tone of

1301.91.text: so, Bill, what should I do?

Well, that is the sound

When you try to deal

1311.98.text:
in an angry state

1313.98.text: not going to listen to reason.

1319.33.text:
He's willing to open, so

1321.72.text:
I think the entire

1323.67.text: needs to go to the balcony.

1335.23.text:
And when we come

maybe everyone will

1346.04.text:
And then he said

1348.18.text:
over Christmas I'm going to

1353.65.text:

Anyway, his mood had

1367.92.text:
Because in order for me to

1375.50.text:
I first had been able to

1377.88.text:
Because when I
was waiting there,

1379.25.text:
in those three hours that

I took some time just,

1384.31.text:
to be quiet by

1386.31.text:
listen, so that I

1388.84.text:
And even when it

1391.08.text:
from a balcony perspective

I could observe

1397.12.text:
oh, all my work is

And instead of

1412.42.text:
So again, just a lesson to

1416.78.text:
is to put yourself
in your own shoes

1418.63.text:
before you try to put yourself

1421.77.text:
how important it is to

1425.30.text:
And of course in doing

1434.72.text:
Now that may seem

but I can't tell you

1452.36.text:
And if I may, I'll just give

1456.66.text:
just to kind of illustrate

1460.88.text:
About a year and a half ago,
I was contacted by a business

1467.72.text:

down in Brazil

1469.88.text:
who wanted my help in

1472.66.text:

1480.58.text:
And he was involved

And they had been

in the courts for

The media called it perhaps

1506.29.text:
It was not just
affecting the parties

1507.83.text:
but their families, the 150,000

1511.21.text: had divided loyalties and so on.

1514.01.text:
And she asked me

I didn't know if I

1517.41.text:
agreed to sit down

1518.87.text:

And it seemed to

1529.35.text:
Or did he really

1531.69.text:
And I think he was torn inside

1534.73.text: What exactly do we want most?

1537.16.text:
Because he was
going to be chairman

1538.62.text:
of the board for
another eight years.

1540.97.text:
He was already 76,
until he was 84.

1544.75.text:
I said, Abellio, tell me,
what do you want here?

1552.34.text:
I mean, what is it

1554.33.text:
And he said, well, I want
my stock at a certain price.

1557.26.text:
I want the elimination of
the non-compete clause.

1563.00.text:
But as I listened

1564.73.text:
But, Abellio, you're a man

1567.06.text:
You've got everything
you possibly want.

1569.78.text:
I mean, what do you

1576.01.text:
And he finally
said, after I probed

1577.63.text:
for awhile, he

1583.76.text:
And then that's when I was

1585.88.text:
And then I asked him, what

1590.08.text:
And he said, well, I want

1592.41.text:
with my family here, which
is the most important thing

1595.42.text:

1601.85.text:
So once we were clear about

then the negotiation with the

1611.57.text:
And even though it had gone

and I just four short

1625.91.text:

1635.74.text:
of the company explaining it,

how important it is to be

So in your own situation, if

it's just always

1651.18.text:
do I most want or need

1654.63.text:
I need, behind the position,

1664.54.text:
In the negotiation
with your kid,

1671.01.text:
What's the most
important thing for you?

1672.68.text:
It's, again,
something that we may

1675.06.text:
lose sight of when we get

1678.38.text:
And where that leads you
to, then the question

1680.71.text:
is, where's the power going to

It's your Best Alternative

1704.32.text:
You know, what's your

1706.15.text: What are you going to do?

1710.48.text:
To have an alternative-- if
you don't have this one client,

1717.08.text:
It just gives you a
sense of-- I mean, to me,

1720.58.text:
this is what the internet,

1724.92.text:
Because in the old
days, when they

1727.62.text: had to go just with one way.

But now you can

1730.28.text: find other ways of doing it.

So to me, in some ways,

1738.62.text:
Now what I've found,
though, interestingly

1740.74.text:
in teaching this
is a lot of people,

1743.15.text:
we don't naturally

1746.28.text:
We just focus on just

1749.86.text:
And what's often

1753.01.text:
is there's an inner

1756.81.text:
to this, which is what you might

1760.02.text:
is your commitment to take

If I go back to the

1765.41.text:
Abellio for a moment in

when he told me

I asked him, OK,

Who can give you the

1788.60.text:
Once he understood that, oh,
yeah, he could give himself

1792.21.text:
a little bit, then

1794.66.text:
even without us reaching

1798.27.text:
He could pursue

He moved his office

He became chairman

He spent time, took

Because he was no longer so

1816.49.text:
on the other side, then it was

1823.32.text:
And so the question
again for us to ask

1826.62.text:
ourselves is who in the end is

1832.46.text:
What can I do to meet my

1836.95.text:
And how can I take

1839.01.text: What would that be for you?

Which brings me, then, to where

1845.93.text:
from in negotiation

1854.35.text:
Let me just actually ask

1858.00.text:
in negotiation we like

But if you wouldn't mind turning

and getting into arm

1873.11.text:
as if you were going

1881.44.text:
As if you were going

1883.43.text:
you can even

So as in business, you want

1898.90.text:
Let's say you get
1,000 points every time

1901.20.text:
you get the other

1914.98.text:
You get the other
persons arm down.

What I see here is there's

1932.15.text:
And essentially there's
a learning process

1935.23.text:
where-- it was like you
two gentlemen there.

1942.31.text: And that's often how we do it.

1943.59.text:
And then suddenly, you know,
if you were super strong,

1945.53.text:
maybe you get the other

But then it was like

1948.91.text: And people said, wait a minute.

1951.49.text:
If I get my arm down,

1954.00.text:
and 1,000 points for me
and 1,000 points for you

1956.00.text:
and 1,000 for me, like

1957.75.text:
And suddenly you're accumulating
tens of thousands of points.

1962.57.text:
We often approach negotiation
like an arm wrestle.

1967.99.text:
You know, who's
going to win this?

1969.97.text:
But in fact, the
greatest power we

1971.89.text:
have may be the power
to change the game,

1974.48.text:
from an arm wrestle to a
search for mutual gain here.

1979.40.text:
And the question for me
is, why is it so hard

1985.95.text:
We often have a mindset
in mind that basically

1990.23.text:
holds that this is, like,
a dog-eat-dog world.

1995.92.text:
And it's ranged against
me, and somehow its scarce.

2002.66.text:
There's a mindset
of scarcity, which

2005.55.text:
is why one of the greatest minds
of the last century, Albert

2015.15.text:
He said, is the universe
a friendly place?

2018.75.text:
This is the first and
most basic question

2022.12.text:
all people must
answer for themselves.

2024.72.text: Now why would Einstein say that?

2027.32.text: Why would he ask that question?

2028.69.text:
Because his reasoning was
in the wake of World War II

2032.85.text:
and the advent of
nuclear weapons,

2035.87.text:
he reasoned that if we
basically answer this question

2042.57.text:
and say the universe is an
unfriendly place-- because

2045.20.text:
after all, who knows--
but if we decide

2047.36.text:
to choose the universe
as an unfriendly place,

2049.41.text:
we're going to see
everyone as our adversary.

2053.15.text:
And collectively we're
going to see other nations

2058.07.text:
as our adversaries,
and we're going

2059.53.text:
to react at the
first provocation.

2061.94.text:
And undoubtedly, we're going
to end up in a nuclear war,

2065.12.text:
and that will be end
of life on Earth.

2068.57.text:
However, if we can choose
to answer the question

2072.84.text:
as is the universe
a friendly place,

2074.59.text:
we're more likely to treat
people as potential partners.

2076.96.text:
And we're more
likely to cooperate.

2078.54.text:
So he thought this was
the underlying question.

2081.79.text:
In other words, this goes
to a negotiation technique

2085.04.text:
which is that one of the
greatest powers we have

2089.98.text:
Take the same situation and
see it in different ways.

2092.81.text:
You could frame the situation
as friendly-- life is basically

2097.77.text:
on your side-- or you can
frame it as unfriendly.

2107.04.text:
And how we do that,
after all, depending

2110.55.text:
on how we make that decision,
affects a lot of things for us.

2114.05.text:
If I might just
use, for example,

2117.06.text:
we could reframe the
picture as scarcity.

2121.09.text:
Life is scarce, and so I'm
going to just grab mine.

2124.22.text:
Or we can approach a situation
from a frame of sufficiency.

2130.00.text:
Maybe there's enough for
both of us or for all of us.

2132.98.text:
And the way in which we frame
that, the underlying mindset,

2136.32.text:
the underlying assumptions
we bring to that situation

2140.61.text:
So these are some of the
ways in which we can do this.

2145.54.text:
But you can ask yourself,
for example, this question.

2148.02.text:
Where does my
satisfaction come from?

2153.04.text: Can I see life on my side?

2154.70.text:
In other words, just
question our assumptions

2156.74.text:
and see if some of our beliefs,
in fact, are limiting beliefs.

2160.03.text:
If I might just use an example
from my own personal life,

2163.44.text:
one of the better examples of
this where I can learn this

2166.80.text:
from is my own
daughter, who is 16.

2169.78.text:
Her name is Gabby,
and she was born

2173.45.text:
with a lot of
medical difficulties.

2177.44.text:
on different parts of her
body, structural difficulties.

2183.26.text:
But she somehow has a

2187.51.text:
She frames things
in a different way.

2190.48.text:
She doesn't feel

2192.38.text:
She develops her
own inner BATNA.

2195.56.text:
And one of her dreams
from when she was little

2198.89.text:
was she always wanted
to be in the "Guinness

2202.35.text:
And so when she was,
like, seven or eight,

2204.28.text:
she tried to make

course in the

And then another one
was she was going

2211.62.text:
to try to put the most

2214.17.text:
Anyway, a year
ago, she announced

2216.86.text:
that for her 16th birthday
she was going to try again,

2220.22.text:
but this time she was

2222.61.text:
Do you know the exercise
called the plank?

2224.36.text:
Does anyone know

2225.94.text:
It's kind of an abdominal
exercise where you lie down

2229.29.text:
and you put your elbows down
and you hold your body straight.

2232.08.text:
I don't know how
long you can do it,

2233.58.text:
but I can do it for about

2236.48.text:
Anyway, Gabby wrote away to
the "Guiness Book of World

2238.73.text:
Records," and it
turned out the women,

2244.01.text:
And when her
birthday came by, she

2246.10.text:
was going to do it at
her birthday party,

2251.00.text:
And we had to get a little

2255.66.text:
just if she did break

2257.67.text:
in to the "Guinness
Book of World Records"

2259.42.text:
and have a certain number

2262.54.text:
And believe it or not, she went

2268.71.text:
And she's now in the 2015 book

2273.59.text:
So I'm just saying, it's

2277.47.text:
who is able to not just take

2282.13.text:
but just to reframe

2285.32.text:
By getting to yes

2287.52.text:
was able to get to
yes with others.

2291.53.text:
In my book, there's
a whole set of steps.

2294.16.text: I've gone over a few of them.

2298.99.text:
Reframe your picture,
which then allows

2300.98.text:
you to stay in
the zone, which is

2303.70.text:
the place of peak performance,
the place of flow,

2306.61.text:
which athletes know
and artists know.

2309.05.text:
And the question
is, can we apply

2310.44.text:
that in our own
daily situations,

2312.59.text:
in our own conflicts
and negotiations,

2316.37.text:
and performance, which
also then allows us--

2319.58.text:
because we've taken care of
our own psychological needs--

2322.72.text:
to be able to respect
people, even if at first they

2328.39.text:
Which turns out to be
key because so often I

2330.45.text:
find in conflict
situations what happens

2332.40.text:
is the other side rejects
us, so we reject them back.

2336.05.text: And then they reject us back.

2337.31.text: And we get locked into it.

2338.98.text: Someone has to break that cycle.

2342.33.text:
It could be us, but
it can only be us

2344.00.text:
if we are drawing on
our own self respect.

2346.45.text:
If we are drawing
our own nourishment,

2348.85.text:
which then allows us
to give and receive

2351.63.text:
and to get into a
more cooperative mode.

2354.03.text:
So what I've found
here is there's

2356.00.text:
a whole set of steps, that are
kind of inner homework, that

2360.08.text:
allow us to get to yes much
more easily with others.

2365.74.text:
Starting with an inner yes,
it produces an outer yes.

2369.67.text:
And effectively
what this does is

2373.64.text:
wins, three
victories in the end.

2375.48.text:
One is a victory
inside of ourselves,

2380.80.text: And the other is a win-win.

2383.25.text:
We're much more likely
to reach mutually

2386.06.text:
acceptable and satisfactory
agreements with others.

2389.58.text:
But ultimately, it also

2391.88.text:
which is it induces
a more generous,

2397.16.text:
allows us to help
the larger whole,

2399.31.text:
whether it's the family,

2411.92.text:

2422.40.text:
kind of an out-of-the-box,

2432.49.text:
And it kind of just

2450.09.text:
But anyway, one of my
favorite negotiating stories

2453.12.text:
that comes from the

2454.87.text:
about three brothers, who
receive an inheritance

2464.63.text:
And the older son

2469.23.text:
The middle son receives
a third of the camels,

2471.73.text:
and the youngest son, he
receives a ninth of the camels.

2474.66.text:

2477.19.text:
But 17 doesn't divide by 2

2482.88.text:
So they get into a
big of a quarrel,

2485.75.text:
And brotherly tempers
start to get strained,

2489.92.text:
Finally, in desperation,
they go and they

2494.03.text:
And the wise old woman,
like a good boss,

2496.34.text:
thinks about their
problem and says,

2497.84.text: well, I don't have an answer.

2499.15.text:
But if you want,
let me empower you.

2505.88.text: So the three sons say, OK.

2510.01.text:
Well, 18 does divide by 2, so
the first son takes his half.

2517.45.text:
The second son takes
his third, which is 6.

2522.13.text:
The third son takes his
ninth, which is two.

2529.59.text: They have one camel left over.

2531.43.text:
They give it back to
the wise old woman.

2534.25.text:
Now if you think about
that problem for a moment,

2537.24.text:
I think it resembles a
little bit the negotiations

2541.81.text:
There seems to be, 17 camels,
no way to divide it up.

2545.05.text:
Somehow what we need to do is
to learn to take a step back

2548.23.text:
to the balcony, change
our assumptions,

2553.60.text:
And my suggestion
is that 18th camel

2560.36.text:
If we can get to
yes with ourselves,

2562.72.text:
we're much more likely to
get to yes with others.

2572.20.text:
So we have some time for
some questions about anything

2578.93.text:
AUDIENCE: You
talked a little bit

2580.30.text:
about this at the beginning,
but over your career

2583.43.text:
with negotiations, how do you
see the internet and technology

2587.26.text:
and even Google and Facebook
changing what you do

2592.58.text:
You talked about how
the hierarchy was

2598.62.text:
To me, it seems like
you see a lot of people

2600.45.text:
going out and broadcasting
on social media

2602.47.text:
and trying to stake
out their own positions

2604.26.text:
and making it harder
to negotiate, maybe.

2605.97.text:
WILLIAM URY: For
sure-- you know,

2607.63.text:
it cuts in a lot
of different ways.

2609.46.text:
But one thing that
is very clear-- it's

2612.97.text:
A lot of people are taking
their negotiations online,

2617.89.text:
And in terms of conflicts
like that, you see-- I mean,

2624.99.text: It's partly cable TV and so on.

2627.89.text:
But you see a segmenting,
where people are only

2630.20.text:
talking to people
who agree with them.

2635.36.text:
And you see a lot of kind of
use of inflammatory rhetoric

2639.75.text:
that goes online and that
before wasn't broadcast.

2645.24.text:
Or you see, for example,
I mean right now you see,

2647.40.text:
like, ISIS has gotten
very social media savvy.

2652.08.text:
They're doing these horrific
beheadings with social media

2657.83.text:
So I think we're just in this
first generation of figuring

2663.14.text:
out how do we deal
with our differences

2666.01.text:
given this whole new
way of communicating.

2669.46.text: And we're in this mix, too.

2672.49.text:
I think the form of
decision making is shifting,

2674.87.text:
but what's also
happening, I see,

2677.25.text:
is that nowadays everyone
wants to participate

2685.52.text:
People are not nearly as
passive as they were before.

2687.73.text:
You know, they were saying,
OK, let the leader decide.

2689.98.text:
No, everyone wants
to have a voice,

2691.66.text:
and you're starting to show
this up in social media.

2694.26.text:
And so in a funny way,
this negotiation revolution

2698.92.text:
means, at least in the short
run, a lot more conflict.

2702.06.text:
Because a lot of conflict that
was suppressed and avoided

2704.52.text:
before, injustice that
there were never addressed,

2706.89.text: are now coming to the surface.

2708.58.text:
And so it's actually to me,
in the field of conflict

2712.91.text:
resolution, I see the task
facing humanity right now

2718.56.text: is not so much how we settle.

2721.63.text:
We can't settle all
these conflicts.

2723.13.text:
The question is, can
we transform conflicts?

2725.87.text:
Can we change their form from a
violent and destructive form--

2731.06.text:
even violent in terms of words,
like you're talking about.

2734.77.text:
Can we learn to use more
constructive and cooperative

2738.64.text:
language, even as we
carry on a struggle?

2740.64.text:
Because with all the
injustice in the world,

2744.06.text:
we maybe need conflict,
actually, to engage it.

2746.91.text:
But can we learn to do
that in an engaging way?

2749.37.text:
And what I found,
like 35 years ago when

2752.36.text:
I started in this field, there
were no courses on negotiation.

2756.66.text:
Now there's every business
school, law school,

2760.98.text:
school of government,
corporations, you know,

2764.83.text:
But I think we're in
the infancy of learning.

2769.10.text:
And what I would love to see
is the kind of creativity

2773.14.text:
and the genius that
goes on here at Google

2775.76.text:
and kind of better forms
of software and everything,

2778.93.text:
but used on the software
of human relationships

2781.71.text:
and used on the software of how
we deal with our differences.

2785.27.text:
And to me, that's
the great challenge.

2787.86.text:
And I would love to see the
mix of looking for the best

2792.54.text:
kind of new methods,
new processes,

2795.31.text:
married together with technology
and see what that would do.

2802.36.text:
I happen to believe-- or at
least I'm a potentialist.

2804.77.text:
I really think that human
beings have the potential,

2807.12.text:
but I think the
jury is still out.

2810.12.text:
We've got this technology
that's being used for weapons.

2815.72.text:
Can we take the same
technology and use it for,

2818.75.text:
as you're using it for,
better forms of communication.

2823.57.text:
AUDIENCE: I had a question about
just different kind of thoughts

2827.69.text:
or voices that you might
have going on inside.

2830.25.text:
So with kind of
the balcony view,

2832.68.text:
you get to really take

2836.79.text:
But then, like, do you
have any personal stories

2840.01.text:
on your journey to
developing that balcony

2843.53.text:
and really being
able to figure out

2845.74.text:
which voice inside
your head to say yes to

2848.58.text:
and developing that awareness
for which ones to say yes to?

2853.10.text:
WILLIAM URY: Yeah,
a good question.

2855.31.text: Yeah, I mean, this is something.

2856.72.text:
I was just talking
with Meng about this.

2858.39.text:
But for me, yeah, it
began with-- everyone

2866.64.text:
has their favorite ways
of going to the balcony.

2869.20.text:
Meditation, for example, is a
wonderful, time-honored, old

2874.74.text:
And for me, personally,
one thing I love to do

2876.99.text:
is-- you have the advantage
here of using nature.

2881.03.text:
What I like to do
is I like to go

2882.40.text:
for walks, just to
kind of clear my mind.

2886.74.text:
Like, for example, when
I was in Venezuela.

2891.66.text:
You need to look for what
methodologies work for you.

2895.56.text:
I mean, for me, I
was looking for ways

2897.34.text:
that kind of, like, change
the rhythm of my brain

2900.65.text:
a little bit, just
kind of put myself

2902.95.text:
into more of a calm state
so that I could clear.

2907.75.text:
And then what I learned was
just a simple rule of thumb,

2911.46.text:
for example, that
helped me was, don't

2915.12.text:
make an important
decision at the table.

2918.07.text:
In other words, when
someone's asking you,

2922.59.text:
Just say, let me
get back to you.

2925.50.text:
I'll get back to
you this afternoon.

2927.48.text: I'll get back to you in an hour.

2928.85.text:
I'll get back to you
tomorrow morning.

2932.40.text:
Just what that
did was it allowed

2934.33.text:
me, then, to go to a balcony and
try to go to a place of clarity

2940.59.text:
Because I find that the
mind's a little bit like water

2946.45.text: that comes out of a tap.

2947.45.text: There's lot of fizz in it.

2949.17.text:
And if you can just put it aside
for five minutes, you know,

2952.86.text:
the fizz clears and
you can clarify it.

2954.75.text:
So I've sort of
learned to do that.

2958.55.text:
And I think everyone will
have their own method

2960.57.text:
for doing that, of how
you kind of clarify.

2962.65.text:
But just buying time, buying
a little bit of time--

2967.28.text:
and I know that in
today's day and age,

2971.10.text:
we're being asked to make
quicker decisions, quicker

2974.82.text:
things, partly due
to the internet,

2977.88.text: It used to be write a letter.

2979.17.text:
It took two weeks to
get back a letter.

2980.79.text:
Now people want an
answer in an hour

2982.29.text:
because they just sent
you a text or an email.

2985.04.text:
But to me the motto is
in a fast age like this,

2990.72.text:
there's a paradox, which
is if you want to go fast,

2996.22.text:
There's a paradox of looking
for ways to slow it down,

3000.79.text:
even if it's just a few seconds
or a few minutes-- breathing,

3008.86.text:
It just brings more
oxygen to your brain.

3010.57.text:
It's just kind of, like, take
a couple deep breaths and just

3013.78.text:
be careful about making
decisions right on the spot.

3017.42.text: And that's been helpful to me.

3021.39.text:
And then I mean the
other thing I'll say,

3023.10.text:
too, is that I'm amazed
at how if I do that,

3032.92.text:
You develop more,
but you get clarity

3034.63.text: about which voice to listen to.

3039.00.text:
And then if I can't do that,
sometimes you can use a friend.

3042.21.text:
You can use a friend as your
balcony or a couple of friends

3045.56.text:
because sometimes we're
blind to our own blind spots.

3048.20.text:
But the friends can
see them more easily.

3051.27.text:

3052.89.text:
A quick question about
cultural differences

3055.07.text:
to people negotiating--
so in your experience,

3058.14.text:
you've seen a lot of different
types of cultures negotiate.

3061.04.text:
Do you think there's one
universal way that people

3065.19.text:
are wired to
negotiate, or do you

3066.62.text:
think there are true
cultural differences to how

3072.12.text:
WILLIAM URY: I'm an
anthropologist by training,

3074.08.text:
so I have a bias here,
I'll have to say.

3076.61.text:
But I do think there are
strong cultural differences.

3079.27.text:
And that's not to say
that there are not

3081.70.text:
some universal principles or
some universal-- so there are.

3086.03.text:
There's maybe a kind of an
under structure of universality,

3090.28.text:
but then the way
in which those get

3098.37.text:
And so they're just different
ways of communicating,

3100.78.text:
but, like, there are
a lot of assumptions

3103.95.text:
Like, for example, around
time-- American culture

3109.19.text:
is one of the most impatient
cultures on the planet.

3113.12.text:
But if you go to other cultures
around the world-- for us,

3122.51.text:
In most other places,
time is relationship.

3125.17.text:
And we want to go there
and do a quick deal,

3128.14.text:
and they're saying, whoa,
hold on for a moment.

3135.79.text:
Or, for example, what's
the nature of an agreement?

3141.11.text:
We have a highly
legalized culture.

3143.99.text:
There are more lawyers,
say, in the city

3146.76.text:
of Los Angeles than there are
in the whole country of Japan.

3151.84.text:
Because we're used
to saying, OK, we're

3155.11.text: going to have a legal culture.

3156.62.text:
And if you don't
keep your contract,

3159.88.text: And we've got this whole thing.

3161.83.text:
In many other
cultures, they don't

3164.21.text: depend on the courts for that.

3165.81.text:
What they depend on is having
built long-term relationships,

3169.27.text:
so that's the way in which
they achieve compliance.

3174.97.text:
One last thing I'll
say about culture--

3177.58.text:
this could go on for awhile--
is I had a friend, a colleague,

3182.81.text:
who was one of the
first anthropologists

3184.96.text:
to really look at
cross-cultural communication.

3190.72.text:
And he coined a distinction
I find very useful, which

3194.18.text:
is he said, cultures are
like communication systems.

3197.52.text:
And he defined it
like a continuum,

3199.86.text:
from what he called
low-context communication

3204.58.text:
In low-context communication,
the content is pretty much

3210.00.text:
In high-context communication,
you get the content.

3212.53.text:
But if you don't
understand the context,

3215.69.text:
So a classic example
of high-context culture

3218.14.text:
would be in East Asia,
say, Japan, for example.

3225.10.text:
historically, was
when the Shogun, who

3228.15.text:
was the military dictator of
Japan a couple centuries ago.

3231.73.text:
When he ceded power to the
emperor, what did he do?

3236.06.text: He paid a visit to the Emperor.

3237.91.text:
They had some tea together,
and then he went away.

3241.49.text:
Note, there was no
signed agreement,

3243.07.text:
I wasn't handing over
power to him, like that.

3244.74.text:
But it was very clear to
everyone in Japan what had just

3247.08.text:
happened because he
went to the Emperor.

3248.80.text:
The Emperor didn't
go to him, and they

3254.47.text:
But the US is a lower
context culture.

3258.72.text:
So that we'll send, for
example, Google or whatever,

3261.64.text:
you'll send someone
down to, say,

3263.01.text:
Latin America, which is
a higher context culture.

3266.50.text:
And you'll send someone
who is the most capable,

3268.53.text:
the one who knows
the most knowledge.

3270.25.text:
He's got all the facts
and everything like that,

3274.99.text:
And they show up
in Latin America,

3276.41.text: and they say, wait a minute.

3279.84.text: They just sent us a kid.

3282.33.text:
Because for them the
social context of,

3284.42.text:
wait a minute, who is this
person in relation to who

3287.59.text:
Are we supposed to
trust this person?

3289.40.text:
So they may not put as much
emphasis on the content

3292.23.text: as we do in this culture.

3297.27.text:
MALE SPEAKER: Having
said that, thank

3298.81.text:
you very much for

We'll do a book

3301.74.text:
and you can check out

3305.86.text:
WILLIAM URY: Great,

3310.79.text:
May you get to yes with

3313.82.text:
